name: Planform Complexity (sinuosity/braiding/side channels/cutoffs)
functionStatement: Examines the role of bank processes and erosion in channel change. Observes patterns in sinuosity and curvature affecting habitat complexity.
descriptionMarkdown:
Compares meander migration rates and cutoff frequency to reference behavior; excessive migration or avulsions indicate instability.
Integrates bank geometry, rooting, surface protection, raw or failing banks, and hardening to summarize erosion risk and sediment delivery.
Assesses whether planform and number of active threads match the natural setting, considering straightening, braiding, and side-channel connectivity.
Ratio of channel length to valley length; higher sinuosity indicates greater curvature and habitat variety.
methodContextMarkdown:
Context: Channel; Floodplain

Method: Desktop; Field
howToMeasureMarkdown:
Count active threads at observed stage and compare to expected channel type. Use a DEM to corroborate bar and corridor patterns.
Compile an imagery time series to map cutoff and avulsion locations and summarize frequency over decades.
Map connected side channels and verify likely connection thresholds at about bankfull stage using field checks or elevation profiles.
Compute channel centerline length divided by valley length in GIS.

inputs.label: Planform Complexity (sinuosity/braiding/side channels/cutoffs)
inputs.helpMarkdown: High resolution aerial imagery; Field photos; Brief field recon; Historical evidence

levels.label: Good
levels.criteriaMarkdown: Good: Condition aligns with local reference for the stream type. (Suggested index range 0.70-1.0)

levels.label: Fair
levels.criteriaMarkdown: Fair: Slight departure from reference condition. / Moderate braiding where not typical, or loss of braiding where it is typical. (Suggested index range 0.40-0.69)

levels.label: Poor
levels.criteriaMarkdown: Poor: Heavily braided from instability, or forced single-thread where braiding is expected. (Suggested index range 0.0-0.29)

references: NAIP and Google Earth historical imagery.
LiDAR profiles for connection sills (where available)
